title: Mount Matin
text:
Mount Matin is a massive mainly snow-covered <a href="mountain">mountain</a> which surmounts the mountainous divide north of <a href="Hotine%20Glacier">Hotine Glacier</a> on <a href="Kyiv%20Peninsula">Kyiv Peninsula</a>, on the west side of <a href="Graham%20Land">Graham Land</a>, Antarctica. It was first charted by the <a href="French%20Antarctic%20Expedition%2C%201903%E2%80%9305">French Antarctic Expedition, 1903–05</a>, led by <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Charcot">Jean-Baptiste Charcot</a>, who named it after the newspaper "<a href="Le%20Matin%20%28France%29">Le Matin</a>" contributed generously to the cost of the expedition.
Mount Matin was climbed and descended on ski on December 5, 2010 via the south-west ridge by Phil Wickens, Derek Buckle, Mike Fletcher, Dave Wynne-Jones and Richmond MacIntyre of the 2010 Alpine Club Antarctic Expedition, who found the summit to be at .
